The "Make College Affordable Act of 2001" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Individuals can deduct qualified higher education expenses paid during the taxable year. Applicable taxable year dollar amounts are $4,000 for 2002, $8,000 for 2003, and $12,000 for 2004 and beyond. There is a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income, where the deduction amount is reduced based on a specific ratio. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2001" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under section 222 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction is based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with a limitation set at the maximum taxable income amount in the 28% rate bracket. The taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year is determined without considering specific sections and after applying certain provisions. Adjusted gross income for purposes of certain sections should exclude the deduction allowed under this section. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition and fees required for enrollment of the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents. The taxpayer can claim a deduction for qualified higher education expenses for themselves, their spouse, dependents, or grandchildren who are eligible students at an institution of higher education. Expenses must be for courses that lead to a baccalaureate degree or certificate. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets specific requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965, excluding nonacademic fees such as student activity fees and insurance expenses. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets specific requirements under the Higher Education Act of 1965, excluding nonacademic fees such as student activity fees and insurance expenses. An eligible student must be carrying at least one-half the normal full-time workload for the course of study and the taxpayer must include the student's name, age, and taxpayer identification number on their tax return. The term 'institution of higher education' has the same meaning as defined in relevant legislation. The term 'institution of higher education' has the same meaning as 'eligible educational institution' in section 529(e). Special rules apply, such as no double benefit allowed for deductions under different provisions, and denial of deduction if the taxpayer elects for a credit instead. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding the exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to expenses in connection with enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year. Prepayments are allowed for expenses related to an academic term beginning in the taxable year or the first 3 months of the next taxable year. Adjustment is made for scholarships and veterans benefits. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is reduced by amounts received for the taxable year as a qualified scholarship, educational assistance allowance under specific chapters, or payments for educational expenses exempt from income taxation. No deduction is allowed for married individuals filing separately. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is subject to certain limitations, including no deduction for married individuals filing separately or nonresident alien individuals unless they elect to be treated as resident aliens. The Secretary may establish regulations for implementing this deduction. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a deduction for higher education expenses under section 222. The table of sections is updated to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a credit for interest on higher education loans under section 25B. Effective date for payments is after December 31, 2001. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a credit for interest on higher education loans under section 25B. For individuals, a tax credit is allowed for interest paid on qualified education loans, not exceeding $1,500, with limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The modified adjusted gross income is determined without considering certain sections. Inflation adjustments increase the $50,000 and $100,000 amounts for taxable years after 2003. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of required payments. No credit is allowed if a deduction for the individual is claimed by another taxpayer in the same calendar year. Amounts adjusted under the section are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. The tax credit for interest on qualified education loans is limited to the first 60 months of required payments. Definitions for terms like "qualified education loan" and "dependent" are provided. Special rules include denial of double benefit and the requirement for married couples to file a joint return to claim the credit. The taxpayer and their spouse must file a joint return for the taxable year to determine marital status according to section 7703. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 25B allows for interest deductions on higher education loans, effective for loans incurred before or after the enactment of the Act, with the deduction applicable to interest payments due after December 31, 2001.
